ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] another temperature profile question
ygData.msgSnippet: Zoran, I looked into it, and it seems there is a bug in setFixedTempProfile in Python.  To fix it, in the Cantera Python modules edit file OneD/onedim.py.

Zoran,

I looked into it, and it seems there is a bug in setFixedTempProfile in  
Python.  To fix it, in the Cantera Python modules edit file  
OneD/onedim.py.  Find method setFixedTempProfile, and add an argument  
'pos' before 'temp' as follows:

     def setFixedTempProfile(self, pos, temp):
         """Set the fixed temperature profile.  This profile is used
         whenever the energy equation is disabled.
         """
         return _cantera.stflow_setFixedTempProfile(self._hndl, pos,  
temp)


The 'pos' argument is a list or array of relative positions  
corresponding to the temperature values.

Instead of using AxisymmetricFlow directly, it will be easier to use  
BurnerFlame and simply disable the energy equation:

b = BurnerFlame(gas)
b.set(energy = 'off')
b.flame.setFixedTempProfile(pos,temp)
...

The reason is that AxisymmetricFlow objects are incomplete - they need  
boundary condition objects on each end.  Class BurnerFlame sets up the  
flow object with boundary conditions correctly.

Dave





On Apr 30, 2004, at 11:58 PM, zorandjurisic wrote:

> Dave,
>
> There is another temperature profile question. This time I am trying
> to simulate an axisymmetric flow for which I have the temperature
> profile. In Python, I define:
>
>      flow = AxisymmetricFlow(gas)
>
> and them I try to specify the T profile as
>
>      flow.setFixedTempProfile([1000, 1001, 1002, 1009, 1100])
>
> For this attempt I get greeted by:
>
>     flow.setFixedTempProfile([1000, 1001, 1002, 1009, 1100])
>   File "C:\Progra~1\Python\Lib\site-packages\Cantera\OneD\onedim.py",
> line 329, in setFixedTempProfile
>     return _cantera.stflow_setFixedTempProfile(self._hndl, temp)
> TypeError: stflow_setFixedTempProfile() takes exactly 3 arguments (2
> given)
>
> Obviously I do not have the syntax for setFixedTempProfile right.
> Help!
>
> Sincerely,
>            Zoran
>
>

Zoran, 


I looked into it, and it seems there is a bug in setFixedTempProfile
in Python.  To fix it, in the Cantera Python modules edit file
OneD/onedim.py.  Find method setFixedTempProfile, and add an argument
'pos' before 'temp' as follows:


<fontfamily><param>Courier</param>    def setFixedTempProfile(self,
<bold>pos</bold>, temp):

        """Set the fixed temperature profile.  This profile is used

        whenever the energy equation is disabled.

        """

        return _cantera.stflow_setFixedTempProfile(self._hndl,
<bold>pos</bold>, temp) </fontfamily>



The 'pos' argument is a list or array of relative positions
corresponding to the temperature values.


Instead of using AxisymmetricFlow directly, it will be easier to use
BurnerFlame and simply disable the energy equation:


b = BurnerFlame(gas)

b.set(energy = 'off')

b.flame.setFixedTempProfile(pos,temp)

...


The reason is that AxisymmetricFlow objects are incomplete - they need
boundary condition objects on each end.  Class BurnerFlame sets up the
flow object with boundary conditions correctly.


Dave






On Apr 30, 2004, at 11:58 PM, zorandjurisic wrote:


<excerpt>Dave,


There is another temperature profile question. This time I am trying 

to simulate an axisymmetric flow for which I have the temperature 

profile. In Python, I define:


     flow = AxisymmetricFlow(gas)


and them I try to specify the T profile as


     flow.setFixedTempProfile([1000, 1001, 1002, 1009, 1100])


For this attempt I get greeted by:


    flow.setFixedTempProfile([1000, 1001, 1002, 1009, 1100])

  File "C:\Progra~1\Python\Lib\site-packages\Cantera\OneD\onedim.py", 

line 329, in setFixedTempProfile

    return _cantera.stflow_setFixedTempProfile(self._hndl, temp)

TypeError: stflow_setFixedTempProfile() takes exactly 3 arguments (2 

given)


Obviously I do not have the syntax for setFixedTempProfile right. 

Help!


Sincerely,

           Zoran
